audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker welcoming listeners to a video tutorial that serves as a follow-up to a tutorial on his blog. He mentions that he will provide the link later. He then proceeds to describe how the user attempts to log in to Skype, enters their password, and encounters a "spinning icon" instead of logging in. The speaker says that this is undesirable and states that you must quit Skype. A loud, distorted buzz is then heard.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating, "Yes, we want to quit Skype, definitely." He continues with instructions on how to navigate the Skype settings, emphasizing the need to quit the application to access options. The speaker then moves on to explain the connection options, instructing the listener to enter a port within a specific range, describing the number as "a five-figure number starting with six."

The audio features a male speaker describing a process that involves entering a port number and connecting through HTTPS proxy, mentioning the challenge of disabling UPMP in this context. He says "you're supposed to enter a port number" and speaks in a relatively clear, informative tone. He then transitions to discussing a workaround for this challenge, mentioning he will show how to solve the issue. The sound of someone canceling something is then heard. The speaker announces that they quit Skype.  He notes that a lot of back and forth is happening to solve the issue.

The audio clip features a single male speaker explaining how to edit a file, referencing the Windows logo and describing a process involving clicking "start", typing commands, and opening folders. He maintains an instructional tone throughout. He further describes steps such as opening with Notepad and editing an XML file, with the aim of disabling UPNP.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing a technical issue. He uses a casual and instructional tone, mentioning that something "doesn't show in the user interface." He then instructs the listener to "copy this here" or "type in this code." After this technical explanation, he details how to paste the code under the "connection" tag. He concludes that it is "very good" and instructs the listener to close and save. Finally, he states "Voila," and suggests restarting Skype to see if it works. The clip ends with speech and an unidentifiable sound.

The clip begins with a single male speaker stating "Okay", then explaining the next action: "Practice Skype." He continues by explaining the next step: "We go to tools, connection options again." He adds reassurance with "And don't worry if you don't see the enable UPMP down here, it has already been disabled in the shared XML file," before guiding again: "So we come here".

The audio clip features a single speaker, who gives instructions on entering a five-digit port number that doesn't start with six. The speaker then instructs to select HTTPS for connecting through proxy. The speaker further references going to a blog with an address that contains the name 'joearisto', and indicates it is a 'blogspot.com' address. The speaker speaks in a calm and instructional tone.

The clip consists of one male speaker who talks in an instructional tone. He mentions ".com" and refers to "updated IP addresses and ports", explaining how to paste certain values into a field. Towards the end, he expresses some relief as he says "it works at last". Background sounds and some voice qualities lead to the impression that it is some kind of recording.

The audio features a male speaker, providing assistance with a technical issue. He suggests leaving a message under the blog post with any challenges and assures the listener that he will be happy to help. His tone is helpful and encouraging, and he wishes the listener a pleasant experience with Skype. Then the speaker says goodbye.
